title: sting singer immigration greece merkel
story: Sting, pictured with wife, Trudie The musician, whose real name is Gordon Sumner, blasted politicians for their inability to solve the refugee crisis but applauded Greece for doing their bit while suffering their own financial turmoil.The 66-year-old, who boasts a &pound220million net worth, said at an Amnesty International event in Athens: &ldquoThank God for Greece because you have shown the way.&ldquoYou have shown how to treat refugees when other people are building walls. &ldquoWhen children are being taken from their mothers and put in cages, you are acting with compassion and generosity and common sense.He added: &ldquoBecause our so-called leaders, a sad parade of half-men, cowards, have not got the solutions.Sting’s remarks come in the wake of US President Donald Trump’s immigration policy u-turn&ldquoOnce again Greece has shown us how to be civilised.Sting&rsquos remarks come in the wake of US President Donald Trump&rsquos immigration policy u-turn, which saw more than 2,000 children detained and separated from parents who tried to cross the Mexico border into the US illegally.Following that, was Angela Merkel&rsquos coalition counterpart Horst Seehofer who has put the Chancellor&rsquos leadership at risk by threatening to pull out of their partnership if she refuses to send immigrants back to countries they initially registered for asylum.Mr Seehofer&rsquos warning comes as part of a major crackdown on immigration as the EU struggles to control its 28 member states&rsquo borders, which could lead to a spike in migration similar to the 2015 epidemic that prompted Germany to take in a million refuges from Africa and the Middle East.Mayhem broke out in the Mediterranean on Friday as more than 900 migrants set off from Libya to reach Europe in just 24 hours.                    EXPRESS1 of 21Nearly 1,000 migrants leave Libya bound for Europe in just 24 hoursItaly may well have been in Sting&rsquos firing line too, after Lega leader Matteo Salvini closed Rome&rsquos docks and subsequently turned away a German boat of 350 immigrants.A summit among all the EU&rsquos member states will take place tomorrow where Ms Merkel&rsquos leadership will be called into question, though Hungary, Poland, Slovakia and the Czech Republic have announced they will boycott the crunch meeting.Austrian Vice Chancellor Heinz-Christian Strache today waded into the immigration row by vowing to do everything in his power to keep his country&rsquos borders closed.The singer, who has a sprawling property portfolio of plush homes in London, New York, Malibu, California and Tuscany to name a few, often speaks out about how he wants the refugee crisis sorted.Though he made headlines in 2016 when he said he felt &ldquodistressed following reports illegal immigrants were working on his luxury 350-hectare wine-producing estate.

As Leader of the House, Andrea will ultimately be the one to sign off Mr Bercow&rsquos admission to the Lords so he&rsquod be wise to keep her on side.Traditionally, Speakers are given automatic admission to the House of Lords in recognition of their contribution to parliamentary life. title: Royal Ascot sun shines for Queen Elizabeth
story: PAThe Queen, arriving with Prince Andrew at AscotThe Monarch, who attended all five days of the racing festival, arrived with her son Prince Andrew in the Ascot Landau Carriage &ndash last used at the wedding of her grandson Prince Harry to Meghan Markle.Dame Helen Mirren &ndash also sporting a floral outfit &ndash Olympian Victoria Pendleton and TV presenter Kelly Brook were among celebrity racegoers at the Berkshire course, which attracts 300,000 people over all five days.The mercury at Ascot peaked at 73F (23C), while the rest of the country also saw sunshine and hazy cloud.The South will see the highest temperatures today, possibly reaching 75F, while the north and Scotland will not be far off at 73F.                Queen at Royal Ascot: Monarch glows in an aquamarine outfit as she ...The heatwave is set to continue with averages of 75F through Monday and Tuesday, with public health officials poised to issue warnings for Wednesday, when forecasters predict temperatures of 86F and above in the South.Anything above 80F can be dangerous for the elderly, young children and people with medical conditions due to heatstroke and sunburn.Clare Nasir, at the Met Office, said: &ldquoBy next week, temperatures will rocket into the high 20s (60s), even low 30s (80s) by the middle to latter part of the week.&ldquoSunday is going to be a great day for being out and about.PADame Helen Mirren during day five of Royal AscotBut remember, UV levels are likely to be high, or even very high, across the country and you&rsquoll burn even quicker if you are on the coast with the reflection off the sand and sea.The warning comes after the UK this year basked in the warmest April day for almost 70 years and the sunniest May on record.The country&rsquos hottest June on record was in 1976, when the mercury rose to a staggering 96F, while July&rsquos record stands at 98F, set in 2015.Bookmaker Coral has made it odds on for this summer to be the hottest ever, following predictions of stifling heat across Britain.The company&rsquos Harry Aitkenhead said: &ldquoThis weekend is set to be a scorcher and right now we feel like there is every chance this summer will go on to smash all the records as the hottest ever.

title: Brexit news UK EU negotiation progress latest European Union countries frustrated
story: Brexit news: UK negotiators leave EU frustrated as little progress madeThe joint EU-UK progress report claimed crucial work had been done on a number of disagreements had been addressed in customs, sales tax and nuclear materials. However, the report also highlighted other disputed areas remain unsolved.While Britain insisted the report represents an &ldquoimportant step forward, Michel Barnier, the European Commission&rsquos chief Brexit negotiator, encouraging Westminster to step up talks on the Irish border because &ldquoserious ergencies remain in the thinking of both parties.Careful analysis of the 117-page document reveals just how unsuccessful both sides have been trying to agree on a number of serious issues as the EU&rsquos October deadline to conclude the withdrawal agreement looms.Westminster and Brussels have agreed on another 2,518 words out of the withdrawal treaty&rsquos 49,049 &ndash 5 percent &ndash since the draft document was made public in February.In March, Mr Barnier and Brexit Secretary David Davis presented a colour-coded version of the draft document, with wording coloured green to represent the areas where the UK and EU have both reached at agreement is reached at &ldquonegotiators&rsquo level.The document was largely considered 75 percent complete before the June progress report, and hasn&rsquot moved on much since, as revealed by the Bloomberg analysis.The new figure completion figure sits just below 80 percent after, excluding footnotes and annexes, just 500 words were added and 68 deleted compared to March&rsquos offering.Many of the changes represent only small tweaks of language and the inclusion legal clarifications to the EU&rsquos previous offering just three months before.                'Brexit pushing Ireland to UNIFICATION' - Irish politician's boast                Majority back tough restrictions on immigrationThis has produced significant criticisms from the Brussels bubble of the UK&rsquos negotiation team and how they have attempted to conduct the talks.One EU diplomat described Britain&rsquos effort as &ldquoawful, describing their strategy as all speeches but no actual substance.The source said: &ldquoThey are really bad negotiators, awful, it&rsquos been absolutely chaotic and they&rsquove not actually been putting ideas forward just giving speeches about their red lines.More publicly, Irish prime minister Leo Varadkar called on Britain to increase its efforts attempting to conclude the border conundrum.He said it was only Britain&rsquos own red lines preventing the post-Brexit relationship moving forward and a no-deal scenario is more likely than it was a few months ago.Mr Varadkar said: &ldquoI think no deal is more likely than it was a few months ago but I still don't think it is likely.&ldquoUltimately, it is in the interests of Ireland and in the interests of the United Kingdom and the interests of the European Union that we have an orderly Brexit and a new relationship that works for everyone.&ldquoThat's what we are going to do over the next couple of months, really try to intensify our efforts to come to a withdrawal agreement, he added.

story: The prime minister of Belgium revealed that there are concerns about the lack of preparations being made in many EU countries as the UK's deadline to leave the EU gets closer.&nbspThe Home Secretary Sajid Javid has already shared a detailed settled status scheme that could allow up to four million EU citizens to stay in the UK.However, he expressed concerns and frustration after officials said they have not heard about what measures many European countries are planning to adopt for the 1.3 million Brits who live on the continent.He said: &ldquoI am concerned that I have not seen any similar plans on how EU member states are going to support British nationals in their countries.                NOW EU ACT! title: high street shops close family butcher succeed
story: arry GomerREXShutterstockRichard Balson outside his family-run butchers in BridportBut family butchers R J Balson and Son are still going strong in Bridport, with 26 generations having sold chops and sausages in the market town in Dorset since 1515.Current owner Richard Balson, 61, says the secret of their success is having just one shop which moves with consumer trends as well as unbeatable customer service.Speaking as the Government launched the Great British High Street Awards 2018 last week, he added: &ldquoPeople always ask me &lsquowhat is the secret of your success?&rsquo I say keep it small. I have seen lots of other businesses start small, go well and then open other shops which run in to difficulties, because they cannot keep an eye on all of them at the same time.&ldquoWe concentrate on offering a pleasant buying experience, which is completely different to supermarkets where you can go round and not speak to anyone, like a robot.                Marks and Spencer told to team up with AMAZON to save retailer                House of Fraser to close 31 STORES, 6,000 jobs cut in High Street c...&ldquoWe like to have a chat with out customers and see where they are from, because we have often served their parents and grandparents.The family business started as a market stall where customers brought their animals to butcher for them.It has been in its present shop since 1892 and serves pork sausages and faggots made to recipes passed down the generations.But to keep pace with consumer trends it now also sells wild boar, kangaroo and ostrich meat, with more than 22 varieties of sausages, including duck and orange, beef and horseradish.Ilpo MustoREXShutterstockRJ Balson and Sons butchers is the oldest continuously trading family business in BritainRichard runs the shop with French brother-in-law Rudolph Boulay, who advises customers on how to cook exotic meats.He said: &ldquoWith people travelling all over the world now they eat something while they are away and when they are back they want to try it again.&ldquoEveryone also wants to be able to cook quickly now, it is all about convenience, so we sell a lot of minute steaks, burgers and small joints. We keep ahead of the game by innovating constantly.The next generation is already involved in the business.His son Billy runs the online delivery service and sells their sausages in a supermarket.Richard also believes one of his two grandsons might one day take over.The shop&rsquos site on the outskirts of Bridport has also been an asset as it has not been hit by the rises in business rates suffered by town centre traders and there are no car parking fees outside.Richard added: &ldquoAbove all you have to love what you do, work hard and be in charge of your own destiny.As the Prezzo announces restaurant closures across the country. We take a look at the retail giants who have closed high street stores in recent years.                    Bloomberg via Getty Images1 of 14Prezzo, the restaurant chain, is shutting 92 branches across the UKThe awards to find the nation&rsquos best high streets were launched by the Government, sponsored by Visa.Suzan Kereere, head of merchant services for Visa, said: &ldquoWe are very proud to be supporting the Great British High Street Awards at a time when the nation&rsquos high streets are transforming.If you are a shopkeeper or shopper with concerns about the future of the high street write to Jon Coates, Sunday Express, Northern &amp Shell Building, 10 Lower Thames Street, London EC3R 6EN or email jon.coates@express

title: Human trafficking Romanian pimp wanted for selling woman to UK couple
story: NCConstantin Mihai is thought to have ‘bought’ a woman from an alleged pimp with wife ValentinaOn his release, he is expected to be charged in connection with a Met Police investigation into a London based Romanian prostitution ring.Nastase, from Targoviste in southern Romania, was in a relationship with a woman, now 26, whom he allegedly sent to work as a prostitute in Bamberg, Germany, where it is legal.However, he is accused of later selling her to a couple in his hometown, who forced her to come to the UK and work illegally as a prostitute for more than three years from January 2012.The case is one of a growing number of investigations ning several countries, that UK police forces are having to undertake due to the number of EU criminals based here.Alarmingly, Constantin Mihai, 37, who &ldquobought the alleged victim, with his wife, Valentina Mihai, 37, was able to move here despite an attempted murder conviction in Romania.Details of the alleged sale of the woman emerged in the trial last month of the Mihais and Constantin&rsquos brother Catalin Mihai, 32, at Southwark Crown Court.They were jailed for a combined total of 23 years.DC Peter Eddy of the Met Police Modern Slavery and Kidnap Unit said: &ldquoThe family had a network of at least 11 women working as prostitutes for them, all Romanian nationals, across London, Brighton, Leicester and Yorkshire, but the main victim, who lived with Constantin and Valentina, was used as a main source of income.The court was told she was made to work on the streets and in brothels in a red-light area at Leyton, east London, and in Ilford Lane, Ilford &ndash a magnet for pimps and prostitutes from Romania since 2014 when its nationals gained unrestricted UK access.The woman handed all of her earnings to the couple.Valentina Mihai controlled the woman, when her husband returned to Romania, but was later extradited there herself on theft charges.Romanian police referred the case to the Met, which set up a joint investigation team with Eurojust, Europol and Romanian counterparts.They found &pound330,000 had passed through the Mihai&rsquos accounts and Met Police seized three BMW cars through proceeds of crime legislation.In October 2017, Constantin, Valentina and Catalin Mihai were arrested in Romania and extradited here.The trio were convicted of human trafficking, controlling prostitution and money laundering, and jailed for nine, six, and eight years respectively.DC Alex Snigorski, who worked with DC Eddy, said: &ldquoThe Mihais are a parasitic family living off the misery and suffering of others. They thought nothing of &lsquobuying&rsquo women and abusing them... to fund their love of luxury cars and property.DC Eddy said the Met had decided to charge Nastase for reasons of continuity.He explained: &ldquoBecause we led the prosecution, it was decided we should also prosecute him, rather than a new one start in Romania, even though his alleged offence was committed over there.Asked about Constantin Mihai&rsquos conviction for attempted murder, a Home Office spokesman said: &ldquoWe will always seek to deport any foreign national with a history of serious or persistent convictions overseas.

title: uk weather forecast heatwave june weather latest long range summer 2018 met office sun
story: WX CHARTSBritons are set to sizzle in blistering heats of 27CThe Met Office said, &ldquoa very warm and sunny day to come for the vast majority of the UK as the mercury is set to reach as high as 27C in some parts.But Sunday will start off chilly.Meteorologist Marco Petagna said through the night and into the morning, &ldquowherever you are in the UK, it will be fairly chilly for the time of year.He added: &ldquoTemperatures will dip into single figures, possibly as low as 5C or 6C in some rural areas towards the North West.                Temperatures set to SKYROCKET as HEATWAVE and HOTTEST day nears                UK weather forecast: Will this summer be the HOTTEST ever?But as we move into Sunday afternoon &ldquowe will see highs of 25C and 26C and possibly even 27C with the mercury peaking in the south of England.Mr Petagna added: &ldquoIt will also be a warmer day in the north-west tomorrow given the sunshine with temperatures hovering around 22C.As we move into the working week, there will be &ldquounbroken sunshine for many parts of the UK with temperatures higher than the weekend.By Wednesday, forecasters are predicting that temperatures could hit 30C (86F).It is the warmest May bank holiday since records began.                    EPA1 of 18Eveyln, 4, runs down the beach with a bucket and spade as she enjoys the hot Bank Holiday weather in MargateChief meteorologist Frank Saunders said: As warmer air from the continent moves towards the UK from Wednesday, temperatures will climb into the mid to high 20s quite widely, even in parts of Scotland and Northern Ireland.By this stage, some places in England and Wales will very likely top 30C - it's not unlikely somewhere could reach 32C (90F).With almost wall-to-wall sunshine we'll certainly be looking at conditions which many of us would call a heatwave.The Met Office estimates the blistering heat will last until the end of June and could even continue into the first few days of July.MET OFFICEAs we move into Sunday afternoon we will see highs of 25C and 26C and possibly even 27CMet Office statistics for the first half of June reveal this month is on track to be Britain&rsquos hottest for 42 years, since the famous heatwave of 1976.The UK&rsquos average temperature of 14.7C - 1.7C above normal - from June 1-14 is the warmest since 1976, figures show.The Met Office said June&rsquos rainfall is also down by half &ndash at just 19mm &ndash follow 82 hours of glorious sunshine.The highest June temperature ever recorded in the UK is 35.6C (96F) at Camden Square on 29 June 1957 and Southampton on 28 June 1976.The highest June temperature ever recorded in the UK is 35.6C Owen Landeg, from Public Health England, said: For some people, such as older people, those with underlying health conditions and those with young children, the summer heat can bring real health risks.That's why we're urging everyone to keep an eye on those you know who may be at risk this summer. If you're able, ask if your friends, family or neighbours need any support.And if you're going outside for a prolonged period, remember UV is high at this time of year so think how the sun affects you and what you'd do to make sure you don't get burned.Heatwave alerts will be sent out by Public Health England once daytime temperatures reach 30C (86F) and nighttime temperatures reach 15C (59F).

title: Angela merkel news germany immigration eu latest news
story: EPA Angela Merkel has been warned she faces a 'German Brexit'Mrs Merkel is desperately battling to hold her administration together as she is backed into a corner by interior minister Horst Seehofer who has called for police to turn back migrants registered in other EU countries.And today Andrea Nahles, leader of the centre-left Social Democrats, delivered an impassioned speech where she vowed to oppose Mr Seehofer&rsquos plans for a crackdown on migration, warning that he is a &ldquothreat to Europe.She told delegates at a party convention in the western German city of Bochum: Horst Seehofer is a danger to Europe.&ldquoHorst Seehofer and Bavarian premier Markus Soeder are on the way to a German Brexit.It has been a turbulent few days for the German Chancellor who is reluctant to change her open-door policy, which resulted in more than one million migrants, mainly from Syria, being allowed into Germany in 2015.                Sarah Ferguson WILL sit with royals at Princess Eugenie wedding                Zimbabwe stadium rocked by explosion as President Mnangagwa deliver...Mr Seehofer &ndash who is also the chairman of coalition partner the Christian Social Union (CSU) &ndash has agreed to give Mrs Merkel two weeks to try and thrash out a Europe-wide migration policy with other leaders at the European Council meeting at the end of the month.However, if no solution can be found with other European countries, he could withdraw his party&rsquos support, jeopardising Angela Merkel&rsquos ability to stay in power.The Bavarian conservatives - the CSU - are longtime allies of Mrs Merkel's conservatives - the CDU.The dispute threatens Mrs Merkel's new grand coalition including the SPD after just over 100 days in office and poses the most serious challenge yet to the chancellor&rsquos leadership.Angela Merkel has served as German Chancellor since 2005 and Leader of the Christian Democratic Union since 2000. We take a look at her political career in pictures.                    AFPGetty Images1 of 83Angela Merkel through the years Andrea Nahles, leader of the centre-left Social Democrats Ms Nahles said her party remained committed to governing with the conservatives, but she said it was unclear if the Bavarian conservatives were still willing to do so.Plans for Sunday's emergency EU meeting, aimed at preparing for a full EU summit from June 28 to 29, were thrown into chaos on Thursday when Italy's new prime minister said a draft accord on migration had been withdrawn due to a clash with Mrs Merkel.Ms Nahles accused Bavarian conservatives of taking the entire country hostage to bolster their support ahead of regional elections in Bavaria in October.Wolfgang Schaeuble, a member of Mrs Merkel's conservatives and president of the Bundestag, the lower house of the German parliament, told the Tagesspiegel newspaper that Mr Seehofer needed to reach a compromise with the Chancellor, that allowed both to save face. Angela Merkel news: The German Chancellor is facing a coalition crisis EPA Horst Seehofer has called for police to turn back migrants registered in other EU countriesThe CSU, scrambling to recapture voters lost to the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD) party in September's national elections, will meet on July 1 to assess any deal reached by Mrs Merkel in Brussels, according to party sources.Mr Seehofer has threatened to defy Merkel if a satisfactory deal is not reached, and to start turning away at the German border people who have applied for asylum in other EU states.However national border controls undermine the EU's system of free travel.Mr Schaeuble said Mrs Merkel would have no choice but to fire Mr Seehofer if he defied her orders.

title: Turkey elections 2018 Recep Tayyip Erdogan opposition rally state TV blackout
story: Erdogan and his opposition Muharrem Ince A presidential vote is taking place later today, in an election that has rocked Recep Tayyip Erdogan following opinion polls being far tighter than he had hoped.If Mr Erdogan was re-elected, it would confirm the transformation of the Turkish political system from a parliamentary to a presidential one after a slim victory in favour of the move in a referendum in 2017.Muharrem Ince, a passionate politician from the secular Republican People&rsquos Party (CHP), was at a huge rally in Ankara where he directly addressed his opponent.He said: &ldquoTomorrow is the last evening. If you have the courage, confront me.                Erdogan on BRINK: Shock poll shows Turkish election on KNIFE-EDGE                Turkey elections 2018: Latest polls as Erdogan threatened by InceHowever, there were signs of a sabotage by Mr Erdogan as he spoke in Istanbul.Mr Ince received a message his rally was not being shown on state TV.Mr Erdogan is hopeful of increasing Turkey&rsquos power on the world stage.If elected for a further four years, he claims wants to help the country become a global superpower.The violent military coup to overthrow Turkey's President Erdogan has 'failed' leaving at least 104 dead and more than 1,500 wounded                    Getty Images1 of 42A police officer talks with the soldiers involved in the coup attempt after they surrenderedHe also said he wants to become the &ldquograndmaster of Turkey as he continues to increase the tight grip of power he has on the country.The President is facing strong and coordinated opposition and there are hopes from the opposition that they could force the leader into a second round of polling.Muharrem Ince has organised three rallies in as many days.The challenger has not hidden away from confronting the incumbent.Fans out in support of President ErdoganMr Ince said: &ldquoLook, that&rsquos my last proposal to you. If you want, I can even cancel my Istanbul rally for you. Come, confront me, let&rsquos debate on tv.President Erdogan has previously rejected calls for a television debate from opposition candidates stating: &ldquoI don&rsquot want anyone to get points through me.Despite this, he is still the favourite in presidential polls with far more coverage on state media than any of his opponents.The challenger Ince has accused Anadolu, the state broadcaster, of committing a &lsquoconstitutional crime&rsquo due to a lack of fairness.

title: defy brussels laws sun says post brexit immigration policy
story: It may comply with Brussels’ rules. So what? Why stick by those after we leave? As an independent nation we should kick out serious criminals we are not bound to keep.Why too are we unilaterally offering all EU nationals arriving by 2021 the “lifetime right” to bring their entire family?What is Brussels offering in return?The Sun is not against immigration. We want only to control the numbers while picking the most skilled migrants to boost our economy. But yet again our Government is rolling over and volunteering new concessions to the EU.Its faith that Brussels will look kindly on our generosity is staggeringly naive.Are the other 27 EU countries now busily reassuring our expats or extending open invitations to Brits? Are they hell.Just as depressingly, the Home Office ­hasn’t a clue how many EU citizens will take us up on our offer. Could be three million, they say. Or nearer four.What’s another million, eh?Their indifference is jaw-dropping.The nation has endured years of belt-tightening and is taxed to the hilt.There is clearly room to borrow a little more and find savings elsewhere. The first option being the £14billion foreign aid budget which even Aid Secretary Penny Mordaunt admits is indefensible.The Tories should cut it by two-thirds and give the lot to health. But it would need a law change they won’t entertain.So they must find imaginative ways to use aid to bail out other departments.The Tories must not impose new taxes. Especially while they still dole out our money to corrupt regimes, vanity projects and charities staffed by sex predators.The public won’t wear it.DONALD Trump aims to strong-arm Nato members into paying more into the pot — with the same brinkmanship he used on North Korea. He has a point too.But the President will be making a monumental and historic error if he undermines Nato’s solidarity. It alone has kept peace in Europe and deterred Russia since World War Two.Britain MUST help keep this vital alliance alive. Not just by maintaining our defence spending but, with the threat from Putin so high, increasing it.Our forces must not be cut further.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: migration big issue eu brexit james forsyth
story: They are acutely aware that for the EU 27 Brexit isn’t the biggest issue on the agenda, migration is.One Government source tells me: “It’ll be a non-event. They’ve far too much to discuss among themselves.”Migration is plunging European politics into crisis again. German Chancellor Angela Merkel’s coalition is threatening to break apart over the issue.While in Italy, the new government is threatening to close its southern border — blocking migrant rescue ships from landing — and open its northern border, encouraging illegal migrants and asylum seekers to head north to Germany and Sweden.So worried is European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker that he is hosting a mini-summit tomorrow to try to find a solution to the migrant crisis which can help save Merkel’s political career.It is tempting to look at the EU in crisis and say that is why the UK is leaving. But this crisis is making it more difficult for Britain to get a reasonable Brexit deal.The European Commission is running the Brexit negotiations.Its priority is in defending the theology of the European Union, rather than finding practical solutions. As one leading figure in the Government laments to me, Brussels’ chief negotiator Michel Barnier “won’t budge off CETA (Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement) with Northern Ireland stuck in the customs union”.This kind of Canada-style free trade deal is regarded by the Government as inadequate.Mrs May and co have long hoped that the member states, nearly all of whose economies would be hurt by such a limited agreement, would intervene at some point and tell the Commission to engage more constructively with the UK. But this is happening all too rarely.One of the reasons is, in the words of one member of the Brexit inner Cabinet: “Only four national capitals are fully across Brexit.”Many of the countries that are most sympathetic to the UK don’t have the capacity to follow all of the issues concerned.Over the past few years, the key to any deal in Europe has been Merkel. She is not now going to ride to Britain’s rescue— as David Cameron found to his cost in the renegotiation.But the German Chancellor could push the Commission towards a slightly more pragmatic approach.However, she is now trying to keep her own governing coalition together, as well as come up with a deal with the French for eurozone reform, leaving next to no time for Brexit.I am told that when Brexit is discussed in meetings she is “visibly distracted”, turning to aides for advice far more frequently than she does on other issues.This situation is one of the many reasons why the Government should have prepared vigorously for no deal: A credible threat to walk away from the table if the Commission didn’t behave in a reasonable fashion would have got the member states’ attention.But Mrs May now must hope the EU can patch together some deal on migration and that the member states begin thinking seriously about what kind of post-Brexit relationship they want with this country.WHEN the Cabinet gathers at Chequers next month to thrash out the UK’s offer to the EU, one of the most contentious issues will be customs.The Brexit inner Cabinet is split between those who favour a so-called “new customs partnership” (NCP) with the EU – which would see the UK continue to apply EU tariffs after Brexit, with companies receiving a rebate if their goods stayed in Britain rather than heading to the continent – and those who advocate Max Fac, which would use technology to minimise border checks.Two Cabinet working groups are trying to find a way to make these ideas work. Neither group has had a decisive breakthrough yet. But I am told the Max Fac one is “not a million miles away” from a solution.The challenge for the PM is to make these plans acceptable to her own side, including David Davis and Liam Fox. One Brexit inner Cabinet member tells me: “She’s got to have David and Liam. If she doesn’t have them, then she has no solution.”Both Davis and Fox support the Max Fac option. But there are influential figures in No10 who remain convinced that NCP is the option to go for. They argue only NCP can help deal with the Irish border issue and get the Government through next month’s crucial Commons votes on the customs union. They warn: “No NCP, no Brexit.”The fear among Brexiteers is Mrs May will use this Chequers meeting to try to push through a modified version of NCP. They fear the reason the whole Cabinet will be present on the second day is to give Mrs May the numbers to do this if the Brexit inner Cabinet remains split on the issue.Doing this, though, would be extremely risky. It would leave Mrs May with a policy that neither her Brexit Secretary nor her International Trade Secretary support.THE Chancellor and the Defence Secretary aren’t just split over how much money the military should get, but what it should be spent on, too.One Cabinet ally of Philip Hammond’s complains that Gavin Williamson wants to “spend the money on uniformed officers when he should be spending it on robotics and the like”.Their view is that this would be a better response to the 21st-century security challenges Britain faces.But in truth, Britain needs both conventional and new, hi-tech forces if it is to respond to the variety of threats now out of there. title: the sun says theresa may brexit bold move

title: uk weather spanish plume heatwave temperatures
story: Forecasters say a Spanish Plume moving over Britain could bring temperatures up to around 35C.Temperatures last reached a scorching 36C in London on July 1, 2015.The Weather Outlook forecaster Brian Gaze said: “Computer models show 35C isnt out of the question in England’s South from midweek as temperatures continue to rise amid a Spanish plume of warm air.”The dramatic temperature is being driven by a heat wave, dubbed the Spanish Plume, moving northwards.Temperatures are set to soar as high as 33C at the beginning of next week — making Britain hotter than Benidorm.The sun was beating down as the 50th anniversary of the Isle of Wight music festival continued today.Festivalgoers listened to the likes of Rita Ora, Nile Rodgers and Kasabian in glorious sunshine as the mercury soared.Average temperatures for this time of year usually hover around 21C in London, 18C in Manchester and 17C in Scotland.But after a Midsummer’s Day scorcher of 24C tomorrow the Met Office forecasts 27C by Tuesday and temperatures then hitting the thirties.The scorching heatwave will peak next Wednesday on what forecasters believe could be the hottest day of 2018.But forecasters now 1957, at Camden Square, London, and June 28, 1976, in Southampton.The Met Office said Northern Ireland could break its 30.8C all-time temperature record, set on June 30, 1976, at Knockarevan, Co Fermanagh, and July 12, 1983, at Shaws Bridge, Belfast.Sunday will see highs of 25C in the South East and London, but temperatures will be well above average widely. Met Office forecaster Alex Burkill story: Cedella Roman, 19, unknowingly ran into the United States last month after running south down a beach in White Rock, British Columbia.As the tide came in, she jogged up a path to take a photo - at which point two border patrol officers told her she had been seen jogging into Washington state.She told The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation: I told him I had not done it on purpose, and that I didnt understand what was happening.I said to myself, well I may have crossed the border - but theyll probably only give me a fine or theyll tell me to go back to Canada or theyll give me a warning.But when officers realised she didnt have a passport, they locked her in a van before driving her 120 miles to the infamous Tacoma Northwest detention facility.She added: They asked me to remove all my personal belongings with my jewellery, they searched me everywhere.Then I understood it was getting very serious, and I started to cry a bit.Mum Christine soon rushed to the facility with her daughters passport - but Cedella was locked up for another fortnight while Canadian authorities verified their authenticity.A spokesperson for the US customs and border protection told CBC that anyone who enters the US outside an official port of entry and without inspection has crossed the border illegally and will be detained.

title: iain duncan smith theresa may brexit talks
story: Senior allies want the PM to seize ­control of negotiations now the flagship departure bill is set to become law.And if EU officials rebuff her demands, she should hand over her business card and say: “Call me if you change your minds. I’m out of here.”Former Conservative leader Iain Duncan Smith has told Mrs May to turn the tables on “bullying” Eurocrats when she returns to Brussels this week.He believes she is in her strongest ­position yet to get them to discuss their relationship with Britain when we leave on March 29 next year.In the 15 months since Article 50 was triggered, they have refused to discuss trade while our own MPs argued among themselves.But Mrs May’s hand was strengthened last week after she saw off the rebels to get the EU Withdrawal Bill through ­Parliament.Tory MP Mr Duncan Smith warned she must show her mettle as she faces the biggest test of any PM in peacetime at next week’s Brussels showdown.He told The Sun on Sunday: “Theresa May now has the upper hand in these talks.They have been watching us fight among ourselves over Brexit for months and didn’t have to do anything because her position was so weak.“They knew there was an outside chance it wouldn’t happen, so they’ve dug in on all the practical stuff such as trade and bogged us down with other details.“But now it has been voted through. We are leaving. They cannot stop it.“I’ve advised Theresa to tell them bluntly to agree to talk about trade or she is leaving.“If they refuse to engage, she must have the resolve to get up and leave the table — making clear she will take our ­£40billion contribution with her.“Theresa must put her cards on the table and tell them she wants to talk about trade now.“If they tell her they don’t want to, she should put her business card on the table and say ‘Tell you what.There’s my ­number. Give me a buzz if you change your minds.Meanwhile, we’ve got nothing more to say to you’.“Then she should turn to her aides and say, ‘We can catch the ten past six if we hurry now.Can you get some cars because we’re on our way.We’ve got work to do. Nice to see you all. OK, guys. Take care. Goodbye!’“That will bring them to their senses rather quickly.“The 27 other EU countries are desperate for a deal so they can sell us their cars, cheeses and potato products.“They’ve tried to push us around for the past couple of years but Theresa has the upper hand now and she must show them who’s boss.”Slamming the way EU officials have treated Britain as “disgusting”, Mr Duncan Smith said: “Undiplomatic doesn’t begin to cover it.“They’ve done their level best to ­humiliate and be rude to us. They are meant to be our friends and allies.”Singling out chief negotiator Michel Barnier, European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker and ­European Parliament co-ordinator Guy Verhofstadt, he added: “Come this week, we can tell them their days of behaving like ­playground bullies are over.”He said Wednesday’s flagship vote was THE most significant bill passed in the Commons since the treaty to join the fledgling ­European Economic Community in 1973.Crucially, it removes any chance of Brexit being derailed and the clock really has begun ticking towards our departure in 278 days.Brexiteers now warn that the PM must finalise a deal by November, to leave time to clear it all by February.Mr Duncan Smith said: “She is in a stronger position than she’s been in for some months.Getting the most critical bit of legislation through last week means she goes to the European Council knowing our departure is now settled.“That means she is back in charge of the negotiation and there is no way they can stop Brexit.“Now it’s down to raw negotiation, and the question facing the EU is how much they want to have a good relationship.“We do, and the Prime Minister has been open about that. But she has to be ready to walk away.“I’ve done negotiations in business and that’s what you do. You say, ‘There’s nothing on the table that I can agree to here. Sorry, I’m off’.“Never buy a car until you’ve attempted to walk out of the showroom at least twice.There is no better way to get the price down than to say, ‘I’m off, it’s too expensive, I’ll go somewhere else.’It’s not so much calling their bluff. It’s calling them out.“It’s kind of like poker — and Theresa has to force them to show their hand.”Last week’s decision to pump an extra £20billion into the NHS — partly funded by savings from EU contributions — will also send a clear message to Brussels that Britain is leaving.Mr Duncan Smith said: “It’s a down-payment that says we have to leave.“It shows she knows we’re leaving and we won’t be paying them any more money after a set time.”But has Mrs May got what it takes to face down the Brussels bully boys?Mr Duncan Smith said: “I think she has the steel to surprise them.“We’ve seen before what she’s like when she really digs her heels in. title: saudi arabia women driving ban ends
story: The change was ordered by King Salman in September last year - with the first licences issued earlier this month - but it wasnt formally lifted until today.Saudi Arabia was the only country in the world where women werent allowed to drive and the strict rules were enforced despite neither Islamic or Saudi law explicitly prohibiting female drivers.It was a historic moment for women who have had to rely on their husbands, fathers, brothers and drivers to run basic errands, get to work, visit friends or even drop kids off at school.Hessah al-Ajaji, who drove her familys Lexus down the capitals busy Tahlia Street, said: Im speechless. Im so excited its actually happening.She had a US drivers license before obtaining a Saudi one and appeared comfortable at the wheel as she pulled up and parked.As for the male drivers on the road, she said: They were really supportive and cheering and smiling.In a few hours, she says shell drive herself to work for the first time in Saudi Arabia.Samira al-Ghamdi, 47, one of the first Saudi women to be issued with a driving licence, said: We are ready, and it will totally change our life.Saudi women with foreign licences only began converting them earlier this month, so the number of new drivers is expected to remain low at first.It will be some time before others learning to drive at new state-run schools are road ready, while some women still face resistance from conservative relatives.Many accustomed to using a private driver say they are reluctant to take on the Muslim kingdoms busy highways.Fayza al-Shammary, a 22-year-old saleswoman, said: I definitely wont like to drive.I like to be a princess with someone opening the car door for me and driving me anywhere.The change is part of sweeping reforms by the kings son Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, who aims to transform the economy of the worlds top oil exporter.The lifting of the ban, which for years drew international condemnation, has been welcomed by Western allies as proof of a new progressive trend in Saudi Arabia.For nearly three decades, outspoken Saudi women and the men who supported them had called for women to have the right to drive.They faced arrest for defying the ban as women in other Muslim countries drove freely.In 1990, during the first driving campaign by activists, women who got behind the wheels of their cars in the capital, Riyadh, lost their jobs, faced severe stigmatisation and were barred from travel abroad for a year.Ultraconservatives in Saudi Arabia had long warned that allowing women to drive would lead to sin and expose women to harassment.Ahead of lifted.

title: fat content menus child obesity
story: New laws are being drawn up by the government to ensure parents can make an informed choice about what they feed their kids.Experts believe they will eat less if they know the fat content of fast food such as kebabs, pizza and curry before they order.The calorie count scheme is part of a package of measures aimed at halving the number of obese children within 12 years.Supermarkets will be banned from displaying sweets and chocolate at checkouts to stop kids using “pester power” on their parents.There will also be a crackdown on buy-one-get-one-free deals on unhealthy food.Tough new restrictions will be place on TV and online advertising of sugary or fatty products aimed at children.Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt will consult food and retail chains about his action plan.He said: “The cost of obesity – both on individual lives and our NHS – is too great to ignore.“So we are taking steps to ensure that by 2030, children from all backgrounds have the help they need for a healthier, more active start in life.”The crackdown on foods high in sugar, fat and salt will be coupled with initiatives to keep children active.All primary schools will expected to encourage pupils to run or jog a mile a day, or cycle to lessons.The action will stop short of banning cartoon characters from popular brands – such as Tony the Tiger on Frosties or Percy Pig sweets.But the current advertising watershed will be extended to limit the number of unhealthy food commercials show during family viewing time before 9pm.There is evidence that popular TV programmes are saturated with ads for sweet and fattening products.Companies will also be given new incentives to reduce the sugar and calorie content in the products they sell.Mr Hunt will consult on introducing clear and consistent calorie labelling on all menus – and removing tempting treats from checkouts.He added: “It is near impossible to shield children from exposure to unhealthy foods.“Parents are asking for help. We know that over three-quarters of them find offers for sugary sweets and snacks at checkouts annoying.“It’s our job to give power to parents to make healthier choices and to make their life easier in doing so.”Last night the obesity plan received broad support.Alison Tedstone, chief nutritionist at Public Health England, said: “Having a takeaway or eating out is no longer a treat, it’s a regular part of everyday life, yet too often menus are information free zones.“Clear and consistent information on menus at the point of choice is the bold commitment needed to help families make healthier choices and avoid obesity-related health problems.”Some supermarkets already restrict sales to under-16s after calls from teachers and experts.Ministers must decide on a 16 or 18 age limit. Research shows the drinks can trigger unruly and dangerous behaviour.Caroline Cerny, of the Obesity Health Alliance, added: “The plan crucially addresses the issue of children being continually exposed to junk food adverts when they watch their favourite TV shows and when they go online.”Chris Askew, of Diabetes UK, said: “With one in three children either overweight or obese before they leave primary school, it’s clear that bold, decisive action needs to be taken. Being overweight as a child can significantly increase your risk of developing serious conditions like Type 2 diabetes in the future.”But Advertising Association chief Stephen Woodford said: “UK advertising rules are already among the strictest in the world.“International experience and independent research has shown advertising bans have little impact on the wider societal issues that drive obesity, which is caused by the interaction of many complex factors and requires a multi-faceted solution.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: at least 100000 attend march calling for vote on final brexit deal
story: Liberal Democrats leader Sir Vince Cable addressed those who attended the march, saying: "My message today is a very simple one: keep fighting, keep hoping, we will win."Businesswoman and campaigner Gina Miller also told people: "Let us hear you shout for a people's vote."Some attendees chanted "where's Jeremy Corbyn?" during the march. The Labour leader is opposed to another referendum on EU membership.Mr Corbyn was visiting a refugee camp in Jordan on Saturday. A Sky News journalist accompanying him on the trip asked him to comment on camera about the march, but he declined.The march's behind-the-scenes organisation involves some of the most senior figures in British politics, including Labour peer Peter Mandelson, Lib Dem Peer Paddy Ashdown and Tory grandee Ken Clarke. The People's Vote campaign says on its website it is "run by Open Britain". Open Britain is a limited company formerly known as the In Campaign, which was designated by the Electoral Commission as an official lead campaign group in the referendum along with Vote Leave.Lord Mandelson, Tony Blair's former director of communications, is listed a current director.The march saw politicians, citizens and campaigners from across the UK walk from Pall Mall to Parliament Square, calling on the government to listen to their voices and give them a say.Among those taking part were farmers, doctors, teachers, delivery drivers, students, fishermen and veterans from the Armed Forces - as well as former supporters of Brexit.Another accused the government of being incompetent.They said: "When the vote took place, we could not have anticipated how incompetent this government would be on negotiating."It's not good enough to say 'the people said this at one point'&#8230"Matthew Mann, originally from south Gloucestershire, who moved to the Netherlands in 2016 for work, said: "I'm here to show what a European looks like."I'm married to a French wife, I have two children who are dual national, and we live in Holland and are caught up in this administrative mess."I have lived and worked across Europe, it's home." There was a cross-party presence at the march, with members of the Conservatives, Labour, Greens and Lib Dems all calling on the government to allow a vote on the final deal that is reached with the EU.

title: game of thrones stars kit harington and rose leslie marry at family castle
story: The actors met in 2012 while filming the long-running saga in Iceland, where they were playing Jon Snow and Ygritte. Her father said he was "thrilled" for his daughter as she prepared to marry her former co-star.Guests lined the path as the couple left the church after the ceremony and showered them with flower petal confetti.They got into an old land Rover Destroyer decorated with "Just Married" paper hearts and tin cans tied to the back. Speaking outside the castle before the ceremony, Sebastian Leslie said: "We are absolutely thrilled for Kit and Rose to be marrying today."Co-stars Emilia Clarke, who played Daenerys Targaryen, and Peter Dinklage, who played Tyrion Lannister, were seen arriving in nearby Aberdeen on Friday.Fans of the Sky Atlantic series had been gathering outside the castle hoping to catch a glimpse of the stars.Two Chinese students, who are currently studying in Glasgow, brought flowers.Yunyao Li, 23, and Qiong dan Xu, 23, said they were fans of Jon Snow."We would like to see him if possible," one said.The impressive castle where the wedding was held, complete with turrets and surrounded by countryside and woodland, can sleep 16 people in the main house but there are more properties in the grounds. story: Mr Gayford said that the birth had been "all a bit of a blur... for both of us", but added: "I won't forget the look on Jacinda's face when she finally held the baby... she looked absolutely just stunned and very, very happy."Little Neve was born on Thursday afternoon New Zealand time, weighing 7.3lb, but the prime minister was kept in hospital for three days mainly due to security arrangements.On Sunday, the little baby made her first public appearance at Auckland City Hospital, appearing to sleep soundly as her parents answered a few questions for waiting reporters.The 37-year-old, who is only the second elected world leader to give birth while in office, said her partner was "being as much of a role model as I am".She added: "I hope for little girls and boys that there's a future where they can make choices about how they raise their family and what kind of career they have that are based on what they want and what makes them happy. title: uk enjoys heatwave with 30c forecast next week
story: On the south coast, Margate's beach was a popular spot, with people cooling off in the sea pools.High pressure has brought settled and clear weather, with temperatures reaching the mid 20s in the South on Saturday.The warm weather will continue over the weekend, though the Shetland Islands may get some rain on Sunday morning.By Wednesday, forecasters are predicting that temperatures could hit 30C (86F). Chief meteorologist Frank Saunders said: "As warmer air from the continent moves towards the UK from Wednesday, temperatures will climb into the mid to high 20s quite widely, even in parts of Scotland and Northern Ireland."By this stage, some places in England and Wales will very likely top 30C - it's not unlikely somewhere could reach 32C (90F)."With almost wall-to-wall sunshine we'll certainly be looking at conditions which many of us would call a heatwave." The Met Office estimates the weather will last until the end of June and could even continue into the first few days of July. UV and pollen levels will also be very high.Owen Landeg, from Public Health England, said: "For some people, such as older people, those with underlying health conditions and those with young children, the summer heat can bring real health risks.Temperatures across the rest of Europe are also steadily increasing, with Barcelona enjoying 27C (81F), Rome 28C (82F) and Lisbon basking in 26C (79F).World Cup fans will be enjoying temperatures of 29C (84F) in Moscow today.The highest temperature on record in the UK this year is 29.1C, which was recorded in St James's Park on 19 April. The highest June temperature ever recorded in the UK is 35.6C (96F) at Camden Square on 29 June 1957 and Southampton on 28 June 1976.Heatwave alerts will be sent out by Public Health England once daytime temperatures reach 30C (86F) and nighttime temperatures reach 15C (59F). Part of the advice will be preventing children taking part in "vigorous outdoor play".

title: jeremy hunt ban shops selling
story: NewsJeremy Hunt to ban shops selling energy drinks to under-18s in obesity fightThe Health Secretary is appalled at new figures which show a quarter of 6 - 9 year olds knock back the caffeine laden fizzy drinks&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNigel NelsonPolitical Editor00:01, 24 JUN 2018Updated07:41, 24 JUN 2018NewsSupermarkets Asda, Waitrose, Tesco and the Co-op introduced a voluntary ban on selling energy drinks with more than 150mg of caffeine per litre earlier this year (Image: iStock Unreleased)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChildren are to be banned from buying Red Bull and other energy drinks in an obesity crackdown by Jeremy Hunt. The Health Secretary is appalled at new figures which show a quarter of youngsters aged six to nine knock back the fizzy products, which are laden with sugar and caffeine. So today he will announce a consultation on plans to stop shops selling them to under-18s in a bid to halve childhood obesity by 2030. Mr Hunt will say: “It is near impossible to shield children from exposure to unhealthy foods. Parents are asking for help.  “It’s our job to give them power to make healthier choices and make their lives easier in doing so.” Supermarkets Asda, Waitrose, Tesco and the Co-op introduced a voluntary ban on selling energy drinks with over 150mg of caffeine a litre earlier this year. Red Bull and similar drinks can contain as much caffeine as a strong coffee and up to a dozen teaspoonfuls of sugar. Shops will also be stopped from putting sweets at checkouts or offering them in buy-one-get-one-free deals.  TV ads promoting foods high in fat, sugar or salt are likely to be banned before the 9pm watershed and there will be mandatory calorie labelling in restaurants, cafes and takeaways. Public Health England boss Duncan Selbie welcomed what he called “bold steps” in the war on rising childhood obesity. Cancer Research UK and Diabetes UK also backed Mr Hunt’s plans. But Shadow Health Secretary Jonathan Ashworth said: “We need bold action not another watered-down, lame duck strategy.”  “It’s our job to give them power to make healthier choices and to make their life easier in doing so. “The cost of obesity – both on individual lives and to our NHS – is too great to ignore.” Supermarkets Asda, Waitrose, Tesco and the Co-op introduced a voluntary ban on selling energy drinks with more than 150mg of caffeine per litre earlier this year. Mr Hunt will go further and make it illegal for all shops to sell the drinks to kids, and is considering putting them on a par with alcohol so only over 18s can buy them. Stores will also be stopped from putting tempting sweets at check-outs where children pester their parents for them, or including them in buy-one-get-one-free offers. TV ads promoting high fat, sugar or salt foods are likely to be banned before the 9pm watershed and there will be mandatory calorie labelling in restaurants, cafes and takeaways.

title: thousands child slaves carrying knives
story: NewsThousands of child slaves carrying knives to fend off gangs behind £1.8bn drugs trade'County Lines' bosses groom kids as young as 11 and force them to deliver cocaine and heroin ordered via special hotlines&nbspShareByDan Warburton20:30, 23 JUN 2018Updated21:02, 23 JUN 2018NewsThere were 5,000 children picked up by authorities last year over slavery fears (Image: PA)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThousands of child slaves are being armed with knives to fend off rival gangs behind a &pound1.8billion-a-year drugs trade, the Sunday Mirror can reveal. So-called County Lines bosses groom kids as young as 11 and force them to deliver cocaine and heroin ordered via special hotlines. But the level of violence is soaring and youngsters are handed weapons in case rivals try to steal their stash. We can also reveal that exploited children are even being “traded in” as gangsters sell off lucrative hotlines. Dealers build up a client base of drug users before selling the list for tens of thousands of pounds – and throwing in their child workforce.  The National Crime Agency believes more than 1,000 gangs are operating hotlines. The NCA has at least 200 live operations in place to smash the rings. Each line can make &pound5,000 a day – &pound1.8million a year. The grim trade sees:  Children having drugs forced inside their bodies – known as “plugging” – and trafficked nationwide. Horrific videos of attacks and revenge beatings shared on social media to intimidate rivals and warn gang members wanting to break free. Recruits subjected to sexual abuse or forced into prostitution. Social media sites like Periscope used by gangsters “like CCTV” to keep tabs on youngsters out on the streets.   Junior Smart, who leads the SOS Project with the St Giles Trust, said: “People are saying this is happening in deprived areas with specific demographics. People expect it to be &shytypically a black youth, hoodie up and wearing a manbag. “That’s not how it works. It can start with simply being offered drugs and within days they have debt bondage and are stuck in the criminal world. “Even middle class children are getting involved because their families have the means to pay off debts and gang leaders can earn cash. “People have been recruited from primary school age. Others have mental health problems, learning difficulties. Gangs hang around school gates and see those who are being bullied, alone and are easy targets. “They target youth hostels, referral units. It’s an immediate workforce for them. One of the biggest problems is children – thousands of them – not being reported when they go missing.” The revelations come just days after police seized a 10in hunting knife as they smashed a gang supplying heroin and crack cocaine from London’s East End to Ipswich, Suffolk. And in April gang leaders Mahad Yusuf, 21, and Fesal Mahamud, 20, were jailed for a total of 19 years for trafficking a teen from Enfield, North London, to Wales.  Kids are promised cash, a flashy lifestyle, friendship and respect. But once sucked in they are invited to share drugs – only to be landed with massive debts that they must work off. It is understood 5,000 children were picked up by authorities last year over fears they were forced into slavery. That was 35 per cent up in a year. The NCA has revealed grim details of sexual abuse, while politicians have told of their fears for trapped kids. Labour’s Ann Coffey, who chairs the All Party Parliamentary Group for Runaway and Missing Children and Adults, said: “The extent of the violence is new – and it’s reaching into almost every small town in the UK.”

story: Advertorial11 best spots in the UK to watch an amazing sunset this summerThis week marks the summer solstice – and is also the official start of summer. So what better time to explore the UK and take in some of the country’s most breathtaking bike rides?&nbspShareByHolly Thatcher14:24, 22 JUN 2018Updated21:07, 23 JUN 2018Advertorial (Image: Getty)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe've been blessed with some decent weather already in 2018 - but this week is when summer *officially* begins. June 21, the summer solstice in the Northern Hemisphere, is the longest day in the year - affording us approximately 17 hours of daylight. Technically, this also means that the nights will start drawing in again now - so there's really no time like the present to get out and explore the great outdoors on some of the country’s most breathtaking bike rides. We've taken a look around the UK to find the best places to watch the sun setting. 1. Museum of Scottish Lighthouses, Fraserburgh, Scotland  A small village called Maud in Aberdeenshire offers a starting place for a traffic-free cycle to the coast. If you're in the mood to learn then head to the Museum of Scottish Lighthouses in Fraserburgh. The sun will set at around 10.12pm this week in this part of Scotland, so you've got loads of time to enjoy the start of the summer. Bike need replacing?   If your existing bike needs replacing, you'll want something efficient and speedy for the roads - like the Carrera Parva Hybrid bike , which comes in versions for both men and women and is now just &pound210 (a saving of &pound90). And if you don't need a new bike, why not have yours checked over before setting off. Like any mode of transport your bike needs to be looked after and regularly checked for wear and tear. Halfords offers a 32-point Free Bike Check which includes:  Frame, saddle and handlebar Wheels including tyres, rims, spokes and hubs Brake system including levers, calipers, pads and cables / hoses Drivetrain including gears, levers, chain, bottom bracket, cranks and cables  2. The Eden Project, Cornwall   Why not spend the day enjoying the amazing sights at the Eden Project? Best of all, if you arrive by bike you'll get a discount on entry. The sun sets on Eden at around 9:30pm on the solstice. Bear in mind though that the Eden Project shuts at 6pm, so you'll need to watch the sun go down somewhere nearby.  Get there in style on the Carrera Subway 1 Hybrid Bike , &pound300. With easy to use 24 speed Shimano gearing, your effort for building speed will be minimised on all terrains, while its lightweight aluminium frame means you can quickly and efficiently ride to your destination. For additional comfort pack an Urban Escape Folding Table And Bench Set , &pound40 (was &pound50, save &pound10) which folds down into a single carry case to make it easy to transport and store.  3. Pembrokeshire Coast National Park, Wales  The Pembrokeshire Coast Path is an absolutely beautiful part of Wales and a stunning place to watch the sun go down. There are loads of campsites in the area, including some unique places to stay. There are plenty of bike routes too, with some offering traffic-free options if you want a more peaceful ride. In Pembrokeshire you can expect the sun to set around 9:39pm. Why not try..   The Boardman ADV 8.8 Adventure Bike , &pound750, is a bike truly made to help you explore new possibilities. White Nancy, Cheshire   Located on Kerridge Hill, White Nancy is a local landmark from which you can see all around the area, from Wales to the west and the Pennines to the north. From time to time White Nancy is painted to look like other things, like a Christmas pudding or with Olympic rings when London hosted in 2012. The sun will set over White Nancy at around 9:36 this week. Need to drive?  Heading further afield to enjoy the sunny days? If you're packing up the whole family into the car for a camping trip, make sure it's in good running order first. A Free Car Check performed by Halfords experts will put your mind at rest. Book online or just pop in to your local Halfords store and trained colleagues will carry out a free car bulb check and check your battery, wiper blades, engine oil level and air conditioning, and check for any windscreen chips. They'll even give you a free screenwash top-up too.  If you're making an unfamiliar journey, don't forget to get the Garmin Drive Sat Nav , &pound79.99 (was &pound99.99, save &pound20.99). With lifetime map updates you're never going to find yourself driving down a newly-closed street or down a disused road. 5. Edinburgh Castle, Scotland  There are few places that are as stunning as Edinburgh Castle, located atop Castle Rock. The views of Edinburgh from the castle are amazing, and a great place to watch the end of the day roll around. Sunset here will take place at 9:58pm. 6. Hampstead Heath, London  The scenery on Hampstead Heath always pleases the eye. This amazing part of London has views of every landmark you could hope for and it's a wonderful place to watch the sun go down. This will happen at around 9:18pm in the capital.   7. Osborne House, Isle of Wight   The home of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert is quite a sight to see. If you're up for the cycle, Shanklin Chine on the west of the island is well worth an evening visit.  Do it with ease - and classic style - on the Pendleton Somerby Electric Hybrid Bike , &pound750. title: britains most pothole plagued roads
story: NewsBritain's most pothole-plagued roads revealed as councils heave with complaintsShocking survey across country comes after study found our roads are worse than in Chile, Oman and Peru, with one expert branding it a 'national disgrace'&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNicola Small21:32, 23 JUN 2018NewsBetween 2007 and 2016, 22 cyclists were killed and 368 were seriously injured due to crumbling roads, with the victim toll rising, figures show (Image: E+)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe nation’s most pothole-plagued roads are today revealed after a Sunday Mirror investigation. We surveyed every local authority to compile the list of shame – the streets that drew the most complaints. Our research was carried out after a study showed roads in Britain are worse than in Chile, Oman and Peru. And they are deadly. Between 2007 and 2016, 22 cyclists were killed and 368 were &shyseriously injured due to crumbling roads, with the victim toll rising. Last year an inquest heard Roger Hamer, 83, died from severe brain &shyinjuries after being flung off his bike when it hit a pothole in Ramsbottom, Greater Manchester.  We found the country’s worst road is Mellor Brook Bypass near Balderstone, Lancs. Motorists and cyclists reported it to the council 545 times in one year. Freedom of Information requests show Seven Hills Road in Elmbridge, Surrey, caused the second highest number of complaints, with 216 reported. Hundreds of drivers signed a petition demanding that the county council resurfaced it. One resident said they had seen FIVE different cars changing tyres at the &shyroadside, adding: “I will be avoiding this road until it is repaired.”  Another motorist said: “Incredibly dangerous trying to avoid huge, deep potholes, having to veer into oncoming traffic. Fed up with damage to my car. “Are they waiting for another needless death? Stop treating us with contempt.” Shocked drivers are hitting potholes and ruining tyres and their cars’ &shysuspensions, steering and underbodies, or losing control and having crashes. Edmund King, the president of the AA, said our investigation shows that right across the country, “our potholed roads are a national disgrace”, and are “fast becoming a national emergency”.  He said: “We are rescuing record numbers of drivers whose vehicles are damaged by potholes. Insurance claims for damage caused by potholes is soaring. “The lack of &shyinvestment on local roads means highway authorities are doing little more than papering over cracks, with drivers picking up the pieces.” He said February’s Beast from the East had made it worse – but was simply exposing years of &shyunderinvestment by cash-strapped councils.  In the first four months of 2018, AA Insurance received more pothole claims than in the  whole of 2017.   Our probe comes after the Asphalt Industry Alliance revealed 24,500 miles of local roads will need to be shut for repairs in the next year – and it would take at least 14years to clear the backlog, costing &pound9.3billion. A separate report by Cycling UK found local authorities have forked out &pound43.4million in compensation and legal costs due to potholes over the past five years. Sam Jones, of Cycling UK, said: “Before spending &pound15billion on new motorways and trunk roads, let’s fix the roads we use every day and are essential for us to get to work and drop the kids off at school.” National roads are to get 52 times more government funding by 2020 compared to local roads. Councillor Martin Tett, of the LocalGovernment &shyAssociation, said: “Only long-term, consistent and fairer investment in local roads can let councils embark on the improvements so desperately needed.”

title: campaigning mum reveals how talked
story: NewsCampaigning mum reveals how she talked cops round after being arrested for medical cannabisCallie Blackwell says she told police she'll keep breaking the law as lives depend on it&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByKaren Rockett21:30, 23 JUN 2018NewsCallie gave cannabis oil to son Deryn&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA campaigning mum talked her way out of a cell after convincing police cannabis should be legal for medical use. Callie Blackwell, 38, was arrested after being seen holding a cannabis plant at a Westminster protest. She has been lobbying for the Class B drug to be allowed as a medicine since her son made a miracle recovery after she gave him liquid cannabis.  Today she continues to break the law by helping parents of sick children get access to medical cannabis through Bud Buddies UK.   Callie revealed she was arrested in February by three officers on suspicion of cultivating cannabis and held at London’s Charing Cross police station for six hours. She said: “I was like: ‘If you’re going to keep me here, I’ll tell you everything I know about cannabis’. “By the end of it they were like: ‘Just go, this is ridiculous’. They didn't even caution me. “I said to them: ‘Well what happens when I do this again?’ and they said I’d probably get a caution. “I told them I’m going to keep breaking the law because lives depend on it.”   Callie’s son Deryn was 14 when he was given days to live after four bone marrow transplants failed to halt his leukaemia . Two months after the final op, Callie risked jail by secretly giving Deryn liquid cannabis.  After five days his new bone marrow finally started to make blood cells. His immune system recovered and Deryn is now a healthy 18-year-old trainee chef. His mum was speaking in the wake of the row over Billy Caldwell, 12, of Co Tyrone, Ulster – who has cannabis oil to control seizures.

title: harry kane swore would win
story: NewsHarry Kane swore he would win World Cup when he was just SEVEN as he prepares for Panama clashThe hero skipper told school pals about his devotion to the Three Lions ahead of tomorrow’s match in Nizhny Novgorod&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByPatrick Hill22:30, 23 JUN 2018NewsHarry Kane has dreamed of winning the trophy since his schooldays (Image: Daily Mirror)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email When Harry Kane leads the Three Lions out tomorrow, he moves a step closer to the goal he set aged seven.   Former school pal and footie team-mate Luke Robinson has &shyrevealed the England skipper – at the time sporting a David Beckham mohican – told him he was going to win the World Cup one day.  Speaking of Harry’s dream ahead of tomorrow’s Panama clash, Luke said: “He loved England and even then one of his biggest dreams was to play for England and win the World Cup. We’d watch the World Cup together and he was always a very proud England fan. “During the 2002 World Cup, Harry had his England shirt with Beckham on the back and the Beckham mohican. “He was so passionate, he was devastated when we went out.”  Luke, 24, was with Harry when he lifted the Essex &amp Waltham Forest District Cup as a 12-year-old in 2006. Now he, like the rest of the &shynation, hopes Harry will lift the coveted FIFA World Cup Trophy on July 15. And teacher Luke said if Harry does win the &shyultimate prize, it will be his proudest &shymoment. He said: “I remember once when Brazil were playing and they had the likes of Ronaldinho, Ronaldo and Roberto Carlos – some of my &shyfavourite players. “I was saying, ‘I’d love to play for Brazil!’. But Harry was like, ‘No, it’s got to be England! I’d love to play for England. That’s the country! That’s the thing!’. He’s that type of guy, England and proud.”  On Harry’s dedication, he said: “Everything was football. If he wasn’t watching football, he was speaking about football, playing football in the park or playing it on the computer. He did well at school and was good at other sports, like cricket, but it was football all day, every day. “In catering class, we had to bring a recipe and make a meal. He’d get a recipe from his chef at Tottenham and cook that so it was healthy. “He’s massive now but at school he was five foot eight or nine, and podgy. He shot up at 16 or 17. He did running and trained three or four times a week. By 16 or 17 he was fit as a fiddle. And someone else tipping him to go all the way is Ian Marshall, the chairman of Harry’s first team, Ridgeway Rovers – where Beckham also started out. And he said: “I bet if Harry won the World Cup he’d come back and see us with it. He’s a class act and we’re so proud. For a club like us to have two England captains in Harry and David, it’s something to shout about.” Meanwhile, England is set for a &pound382million party as it cheers on Harry and his boys today.  Retail experts reckon &pound65million will be spent in pubs, cafes and restaurants and &pound151million will go on food and drink at home. Some &pound20million will go on flags and souvenirs, &pound68million on shirts and &pound67million on TVs, website VoucherCodes and the Centre for Retail Research said.  Tesco expects to sell 140 million bottles and cans of beer. The chain’s booze boss Rob Cooke said: “There’s a real party atmosphere.”  Big brother's watching you Harry Kane has his biggest fan cheering him on in Russia – his lookalike older brother Charlie.

title: inexcusable report gosport gathered dust
story: NewsopinionInexcusable report into Gosport gathered dust for 10 years, says Shadow health secretary Jonathan AshworthThe report is clear: concerns were first raised in 1991 but Gosport War Memorial Hospital chose not to rectify the practise of prescribing the drugs involved&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJonathan Ashworth22:30, 23 JUN 2018NewsopinionAn inquiry was conduced which found an 'almost routine use of opiates' since 1998 at The Gosport War Memorial Hospital in Gosport, Hampshire (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe learned this week the harrowing truth and extent of the poor care in Gosport War Memorial Hospital two decades ago. Our thoughts must be with the families of those 450 patients whose lives were shortened. What have learned this week has been quite simply devastating, shocking and heartbreaking. I pay tribute to my Liberal Democrat parliamentary colleague Norman Lamb for establishing the inquiry as minister and I thank the inquiry panel who has shown extraordinary dedication, under the calm, compassionate, relentless, determined leadership of the former Bishop of Liverpool James Jones in uncovering an injustice and revealing the truth about a shameful episode in our nation’s recent history. The Report is clear, concerns were first raised in 1991 but the hospital chose not to rectify the practise of prescribing the drugs involved. An inquiry was conduced which found an “almost routine use of opiates” since 1998, which “almost certainly shortened the lives of some patients”. But inexcusably this report was left to gather dust on a shelf for ten years. As the Rt Reverend Jones says, handing over a loved one to a hospital, to doctors and nurses, is an act of trust. That trust was betrayed. He goes on: “a large number of patients and their relatives understood that their admission to the hospital was for either rehabilitation or respite, they were, in effect, put on a terminal care pathway.” Others will come to their own judgement but for me that is unforgivable.
